headline: Asia Morning Briefing: Trump's E.U. Tariff Deal Holds Bitcoin Near $119K
summary: Good Morning, Asia. Here's what's making news in the markets: Welcome to Asia Morning Briefing, a daily summary of top stories during U.S. hours and an overview of market moves and analysis. For a detailed overview of U.S. markets, see CoinDesk's Crypto Daybook Americas. Bitcoin (BTC) traded at $119,430 in early Asia hours on Monday, up 1.24%, as bullish momentum continued following a series of institutional milestones and a breakthrough trade deal between the United States and the European Union. The CoinDesk 20 (CD20) Index rose 2.37% to 4,099.18, extending its recent recovery. Over the weekend, President Donald Trump and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen announced a framework trade agreement at Turnberry, Scotland, that sets a 15% U.S. import tariff on E.U. goods, avoiding the previously threatened 30% rate. The deal includes $600 billion in E.U. investment in U.S. energy and defense over the next three years and aims to reduce Europe‚Äôs reliance on Russian fuel. Tariffs on steel and aluminum remain at 50% for the time being. At the same time, bitcoin‚Äôs realized market capitalization, a measure of the total value of BTC based on the last time each coin moved, crossed the $1 trillion threshold for the first time , according to Glassnode. All this comes as BTC continues to consolidate above $118,000 after hitting a record high of $122,700 last week. The rally triggered significant long-term holder selling, while drawing in new buyers and fresh capital. BTC dominance, which measures Bitcoin‚Äôs market share relative to the total crypto market, has edged down to 60.98%, suggesting modest rotation into altcoins. On Friday, Galaxy Digital announced it had executed a $9 billion BTC transaction on behalf of a Satoshi-era investor, one of the largest single bitcoin transfers in history. The sale involved 80,000 BTC and was reportedly part of an estate planning strategy. The lack of price movement despite the size of the deal is likely a testament to how much BTC is illiquid, thanks to long-term HODLing. A market on the verge of a supply-shock rally can take an extra $9 billion being placed up for sale. Meanwhile, Polymarket bettors now give BTC a 24% chance of hitting $125,000 before the end of July, up from 18% earlier in the week. The increased odds come as traders weigh the impact of macro tailwinds and growing on-chain conviction. Market Movements BTC: Bitcoin is trading above $119K as the United States and European Union sign a trade agreement, while CoinGlass data shows that traders have dipped into the majority short positions. ETH: Ether is trading at $3,867.76, up 3%, amid strong onchain fundamentals: 28% of ETH is staked, exchange balances are at eight-year lows, and new buyer inflows are rising. Gold: Gold is down for a fourth straight day, trading around $3,335 in early Asia despite a 28% year-to-date gain, as progress on U.S.‚ÄìEU and U.S.‚ÄìChina trade deals reduces safe-haven demand ahead of this week‚Äôs FOMC meeting. Nikkei 225: Asia-Pacific markets traded mixed Monday as investors awaited details of U.S.‚ÄìChina trade talks. headline: Altcoin Season Index: Unveiling the Current Bitcoin Market Dominance
summary: BitcoinWorld Altcoin Season Index: Unveiling the Current Bitcoin Market Dominance The cryptocurrency market is a dynamic and constantly shifting landscape. Right now, a crucial metric, the Altcoin Season Index , stands at 43 as of 00:30 UTC on July 28. This specific reading from CoinMarketCap (CMC) signals that we are firmly entrenched in what‚Äôs known as ‚ÄòBitcoin Season‚Äô. But what exactly does this indicator mean for your digital asset portfolio, and how should astute investors navigate these prevailing market currents? What Exactly is the Altcoin Season Index, and How Does It Work? To understand current market dynamics, it‚Äôs essential to grasp the mechanics behind the Altcoin Season Index . Developed by CoinMarketCap, this index offers a clear snapshot of the broader crypto market‚Äôs performance. It compares the performance of the top 100 cryptocurrencies by market capitalization (excluding stablecoins and wrapped tokens) against Bitcoin over a rolling 90-day period. The index‚Äôs score indicates whether altcoins are outperforming Bitcoin (higher score) or if Bitcoin is dominating (lower score). Here‚Äôs how different market phases are defined: Index Score Range Market State Definition (vs. Bitcoin over 90 days) 75-100 Altcoin Season At least 75% of top 100 altcoins outperformed Bitcoin. 26-74 Bitcoin Season 25% or fewer of top 100 altcoins outperformed Bitcoin. 1-25 Bitcoin Dominance Very few altcoins performing well against Bitcoin. Our current reading of 43 places us firmly in ‚ÄòBitcoin Season‚Äô, indicating that the majority of altcoins are struggling to keep pace with Bitcoin‚Äôs momentum, and capital is largely flowing into or remaining within Bitcoin. Why Are We Experiencing Bitcoin Season Right Now? Unpacking the Drivers The shift towards Bitcoin Season is influenced by a confluence of macroeconomic factors, market sentiment, and unique cryptocurrency dynamics. Several key drivers contribute to Bitcoin‚Äôs current outperformance, pushing the Altcoin Season Index lower: Macroeconomic Uncertainty: In times of global economic instability or rising interest rates, investors often seek ‚Äòsafer‚Äô assets. Bitcoin, increasingly viewed as ‚Äòdigital gold‚Äô within crypto, attracts capital away from more speculative altcoins. Institutional Adoption: A significant portion of institutional capital entering crypto initially focuses on Bitcoin. The approval of Bitcoin spot ETFs, for instance, provides regulated access for large financial entities, creating consistent buying pressure for Bitcoin not always seen in altcoins. Bitcoin Halving Narrative: The anticipation of Bitcoin‚Äôs programmed supply shock (halving) often drives accumulation. This strong bullish sentiment for Bitcoin can overshadow altcoin performance in the pre-halving and immediate post-halving periods. Market Liquidity: Bitcoin‚Äôs vast market capitalization offers superior liquidity, allowing it to absorb large orders with less volatility. When overall market liquidity tightens, funds often consolidate into Bitcoin. Navigating the Currents: Strategic Approaches for Investors During Bitcoin Season Understanding that we are in Bitcoin Season, as indicated by the Altcoin Season Index at 43, is crucial. Adapting your investment strategy can help you navigate these conditions effectively: Focus on Bitcoin Accumulation: Many investors prioritize accumulating Bitcoin during this period, given its historical resilience and role as the primary gateway for institutional money. Strategic Altcoin Selection: Not all altcoins will suffer equally. This period demands highly selective investment. Look for projects with: Strong Fundamentals: Clear use cases, robust technology, and demonstrable adoption. Active Development: Teams consistently delivering updates and hitting roadmap milestones. Niche Strength: Leadership in high-growth sectors like AI integration, Real World Assets (RWA) tokenization, or Layer 2 scaling solutions. Embrace Dollar-Cost Averaging (DCA): Regularly investing a fixed amount into Bitcoin and selected altcoins, regardless of price, can average out your purchase price over time and mitigate short-term volatility. Prioritize Risk Management: Diversify holdings, set realistic profit targets, and consider stop-loss orders. Avoid over-allocating to single, highly speculative altcoin projects during a Bitcoin-dominated phase. Deep Dive Research: Bitcoin Season is ideal for extensive research into promising altcoin projects. Understanding their technology, tokenomics, and competitive landscape prepares you for future shifts. When Will the Tide Turn? Predicting the Next Altcoin Season While Bitcoin currently dominates, market cycles are fundamental to cryptocurrency. The question is: when will the Altcoin Season Index begin its ascent, signaling altcoin dominance? Several factors typically precede this shift: Bitcoin Price Consolidation: After a strong run, Bitcoin often enters a period of sideways trading or minor pullbacks. This stability allows capital to seek opportunities elsewhere. Capital Rotation: As investors realize profits from Bitcoin, a portion often rotates into altcoins, seeking higher percentage gains. New Narratives and Innovation: Breakthroughs or popular trends (e.g., DeFi, NFTs, AI crypto) can draw significant attention and capital specifically into altcoin projects. Reduced Market Uncertainty: Improved macroeconomic conditions or regulatory clarity can boost overall investor confidence, increasing appetite for altcoin risk. Monitoring the Altcoin Season Index itself will be paramount. A sustained upward trend, especially breaking above 75, would be a definitive signal of altcoins taking the lead. Challenges and Opportunities in a Bitcoin-Dominated Market Operating within a Bitcoin Season, as indicated by the Altcoin Season Index , presents both challenges and opportunities. Challenges: Increased Volatility for Altcoins: Altcoins are susceptible to sharp declines if Bitcoin corrects, often lacking the same liquidity and institutional backing. Capital Drain: Funds flowing primarily into Bitcoin can lead to stagnant or declining altcoin prices. Difficulty in Picking Winners: Identifying altcoins poised for independent growth during Bitcoin dominance requires extensive research. Opportunities: Strategic Accumulation: Bitcoin Season is an excellent time to acquire high-potential altcoins at discounted prices, building stronger positions for future gains. Refined Research: The slower pace allows for thorough due diligence on whitepapers, tokenomics, and teams, without the pressure of rapidly moving prices. Identifying Future Leaders: Diligent research can pinpoint innovative projects that might lead the next bull cycle, even if currently overshadowed by Bitcoin. This proactive approach can yield significant rewards when the Altcoin Season Index eventually turns. Conclusion: Navigating the Seasons with Knowledge The current Altcoin Season Index reading of 43 clearly indicates a Bitcoin Season. This period, characterized by Bitcoin‚Äôs outperformance, is a natural phase in the cyclical nature of the cryptocurrency market. While it might feel challenging for altcoin holders, it‚Äôs an opportunity for strategic positioning and informed decision-making. Understanding the drivers of Bitcoin‚Äôs dominance and implementing robust investment strategies, such as focusing on strong fundamentals, employing dollar-cost averaging, and prioritizing risk management, can help investors navigate these waters effectively. Keep a keen eye on the Altcoin Season Index , as its movement will be a key indicator of when market dynamics might shift again, ushering in the next exhilarating Altcoin Season. Patience, continuous learning, and adaptability remain your most valuable assets in the ever-unpredictable world of crypto. Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) 1. What exactly is the Altcoin Season Index? The Altcoin Season Index is a metric by CoinMarketCap that measures the performance of the top 100 altcoins against Bitcoin over a 90-day period. It indicates whether the market is in ‚ÄòAltcoin Season‚Äô or ‚ÄòBitcoin Season‚Äô. 2. How is Altcoin Season determined by the index? Altcoin Season is declared when at least 75% of the top 100 altcoins have outperformed Bitcoin over the past 90 days, corresponding to an index score of 75-100. 3. What does it mean if the Altcoin Season Index is at 43? An Altcoin Season Index reading of 43 indicates ‚ÄòBitcoin Season‚Äô. This means 25% or fewer of the top 100 altcoins have outperformed Bitcoin over the last 90 days, signifying Bitcoin‚Äôs current dominance. 4. Should I sell all my altcoins during Bitcoin Season? Not necessarily. Bitcoin Season can be a chance to accumulate high-potential altcoins at lower prices. Focus on research, strong fundamentals, and risk management rather than impulsive decisions. 5. How can I prepare for the next Altcoin Season? Prepare by researching promising altcoin projects, understanding their technology, and considering dollar-cost averaging. Monitoring the Altcoin Season Index for a sustained upward trend is also key. 6. Does the Altcoin Season Index guarantee future market movements? No, the Altcoin Season Index is a historical and current performance indicator, not a predictor. It reflects past trends and sentiment, but the crypto market is volatile. Use it as one tool among many in your analysis. Did you find this deep dive into the Altcoin Season Index and Bitcoin Season insightful? headline: Did El Salvador fake Bitcoin buys to scam the IMF?
summary: In 2021, El Salvador became the first country in the world to make Bitcoin legal tender. President Nayib Bukele said the decision would help the country break free from relying on the US dollar and lower the high costs of sending and receiving money. The government launched the Chivo Wallet, set up Bitcoin ATMs, promised a tax-free ‚ÄúBitcoin City,‚Äù and planned to raise $1b through ‚ÄúVolcano Bonds‚Äù to advance its digital agenda . But what stood out the most was the president‚Äôs promise to buy one Bitcoin every day starting in November 2022, and for more than two years, his administration claimed it did. On top of that, the government constantly highlighted its commitment to Bitcoin by posting updates about new purchases every week on social media . They used sites like Nayib Tracker to show off the country‚Äôs growing reserves and convince everyone that El Salvador wasn‚Äôt backing down. Bitcoin circles praised the country for standing up to traditional finance systems and leading the way for other developing nations, while crypto enthusiasts said its boldness was visionary. In reality, El Salvador urgently needed money. The country faced rising debt, a growing budget gap, and increasing pressure to rebuild trust with international lenders. The financial situation was more fragile than it seemed, so the government quietly worked out a $1.4 billion loan deal with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), agreeing to follow strict conditions to get the support it needed. In July 2025, the IMF review revealed El Salvador hadn‚Äôt bought any new Bitcoin since February, just weeks after finalizing the deal. This shocking news raised a big question: Did El Salvador believe in Bitcoin, or was it just putting on a show to get money from the IMF? Officials told one story to the IMF and another to the public El Salvador faced growing debt and economic pressure by late 2024. Its bold Bitcoin experiment grabbed headlines but failed to attract the broad economic relief the government expected. While tourism rose slightly and a few Bitcoin influencers showed interest, issues like rising deficits, weak public trust, stalled projects, and a broken Chivo Wallet remained unresolved. The government had no choice but to turn to the IMF (an organization it once resisted) for help because it urgently needed to secure reliable funding. After months of talks, El Salvador secured a 40-month, $1.4 billion loan from the IMF in December 2024. The deal aimed to stabilize the economy and rebuild trust with global partners and investors, but also came with strict conditions. The country agreed to stop buying more Bitcoin, make its use optional instead of mandatory, limit government control of the Chivo Wallet, and increase transparency in all state-run crypto activities. The government quietly told the IMF it had stopped buying Bitcoin in February 2025 but kept that information from the public. Instead, President Bukele and the National Bitcoin Office kept posting on social media as if they were still buying Bitcoin every day. The new IMF report released in July 2025 revealed that there had been no new public Bitcoin purchases for months. A letter was attached to the review stating that ‚Äúthe stock of Bitcoins held by the public sector remains unchanged.‚Äù Worse, it was signed by the country‚Äôs central bank president and the finance minister. A small but telling detail in footnote nine revealed that the rise in El Salvador‚Äôs Bitcoin reserve came from moving existing Bitcoin between wallets and not from new purchases or market gains. In short, the government was just shifting Bitcoin between its own wallets, rearranging its holdings without adding anything new. The government carefully followed the IMF‚Äôs rules to unlock funding and keep creditors happy, while still pretending to the public that it was fully committed to Bitcoin and daily buys. Leaders faked Bitcoin buys to secure a $1.4b loan Did the government knowingly mislead the public about buying Bitcoin, or was it just using a smart strategy to get funding while keeping its crypto image alive? That‚Äôs the question at the heart of El Salvador‚Äôs Bitcoin saga. It was clear that President Bukele‚Äôs team and top financial advisors entered IMF talks knowing the loan required big changes to their digital asset policies. Yet they kept making public claims that told a different story, even after agreeing to the terms and confirming compliance in official documents sent to the IMF in early 2025. The government‚Äôs mixed messaging showed a clear strategy: win over both the public and global lenders. It not only cooperated with the IMF, accepted strict conditions, and secured not just the $1.4 billion loan in private, but also got over $2 billion more from the World Bank and IDB. The government faced public pressure to protect its crypto image as it met IMF demands behind the scenes. Bukele had used Bitcoin to brand El Salvador as a bold, tech-driven nation challenging global powers since 2021. The story drew media attention, crypto tourists, and praise from Bitcoin supporters. Admitting it had stopped buying Bitcoin or was following IMF rules could damage that image, show weakness, and change their story from rebellion to retreat. For this reason, the government likely chose to balance truth and image out of political and economic need and not out of malice. It protected its brand, energized supporters, and postponed the fallout of changing course by keeping the Bitcoin buying story alive. It also unlocked vital funding, kept creditors calm, and avoided deeper economic trouble by quietly following IMF rules. This double strategy offered short-term rewards but relied on a fragile illusion that could fall apart if people saw the gap between what the government said and what it actually did. El Salvador‚Äôs story sends a warning to other countries El Salvador never said it had stopped using Bitcoin, but behind the scenes, it quietly let key parts of the story fade while still showing strong support in public. This double strategy worked for a while because the IMF got its reforms, and the crypto world kept believing. But in July 2025, the IMF report confirmed the government hadn‚Äôt bought any Bitcoin since February. That revealed the truth and showed how weak the Bitcoin experiment was when real economic pressure hit. El Salvador‚Äôs example is a warning for countries in Africa, Southeast Asia, and Latin America, considering similar experiments. It tried to lead the way in using Bitcoin as national policy, but the bold experiment gave way to quiet retreat when debt, weak systems, and real-world demands hit. Bitcoin didn‚Äôt fail because the technology still works. But without transparency, solid rules, and reliable infrastructure, the plan was never built to last. This raises a bigger question: Can Bitcoin really work as national policy, or is it too unstable and risky to last? Are governments serious about change, or just using crypto to distract the public, delay tough choices, and polish their image? In El Salvador‚Äôs case, the picture is clear. Bitcoin brought attention, boosted the president‚Äôs popularity, and created an image of progress.
